Understanding EHC Plans

  3. Understanding EHC Plans

An EHC plan is a legal document that describes your child's special educational needs and the support they must receive. It covers education, health and social care.

What an EHC plan does

An Education, Health and Care (EHC) plan:

  • describes your child's special educational needs
  • sets out the outcomes you and your child want to achieve
  • lists the specific support your child must receive
  • names the school or other setting your child will attend

The council has a legal duty to make sure all the educational support written in the plan is provided. This is not optional — it is the law.

What is in an EHC plan

An EHC plan has several sections, labelled A to K. Here is what each one covers:

Section A: Your child's views and aspirations

What your child wants for their future, their interests, and what is important to them. Your views as parents are included here too.

Section B: Special educational needs

A full description of your child's special educational needs. This section is legally binding.

Section C: Health needs

Any health needs your child has that are related to their SEND.

Section D: Social care needs

Any social care needs related to their SEND.

Section E: Outcomes

The goals everyone is working towards for your child.

Section F: Educational support

The specific educational support your child must receive. This section is legally binding. The council must provide everything listed here.

Section G: Health support

Health provision your child needs. This section is legally binding on the NHS.

Sections H1 and H2: Social care support

Social care provision, including any support under the Children Act 1989.

Section I: School or placement

The name of the school or other setting your child will attend.

Section J: Personal budget

Details of any personal budget, if you have requested one.

Section K: Appendices

All the professional advice and reports gathered during the assessment.

Choosing a school

When your child has an EHC plan, you have the right to ask for a particular school. The council must name your preferred school unless:

  • it is unsuitable for your child's needs
  • your child attending would be incompatible with the education of other children there
  • it would be an inefficient use of resources

The law says children with EHC plans should be educated in mainstream schools unless this is against the parents' wishes or is genuinely incompatible with the efficient education of others.

Types of school placement include:

  • mainstream school or academy
  • mainstream school with a specialist resourced unit
  • maintained special school
  • independent special school (approved under section 41)
  • further education college
  • specialist post-16 institution

Annual reviews

Your child's EHC plan must be reviewed at least once a year. The annual review looks at whether your child is making progress towards their outcomes and whether the plan needs to change.

What happens at a review

  1. The school sends out invitations and paperwork at least 2 weeks before the meeting
  2. A review meeting is held — you and your child should be invited
  3. The school sends recommendations to the council within 2 weeks of the meeting
  4. The council decides within 4 weeks whether to keep the plan as it is, change it, or end it

Key transition reviews

Starting school: review by 31 March in the year before school entry
Moving to secondary: review by 31 March in Year 5
Moving to post-16: review by 31 March in Year 9, and every year after

Personal budgets

You have the right to request a personal budget when an EHC plan is being prepared or reviewed. A personal budget gives you more control over how the support in the plan is delivered.

There are different ways a personal budget can work:

  • Direct payment — money paid to you so you can arrange support yourself
  • Arranged provision — a provider delivers support on behalf of the council
  • Notional budget — the school uses funding flexibly to meet needs

When an EHC plan ends

An EHC plan may be ended (ceased) when:

  • the young person is no longer in education or training
  • the young person reaches age 25
  • the council decides the plan is no longer needed because your child's needs can be met without it

You have the right to appeal if the council decides to end your child's EHC plan and you disagree. Read about your rights and how to appeal.

Remember

Sections B, F and G of the EHC plan are legally binding. The council and NHS must provide everything listed in those sections.
